e4: Changing to the new policy could have short-term consequences for company stock performance, potentially leading to a negative perception by investors until a consistent adjustment to the new methodology is fully communicated. A long-term solution may involve implementing clear disclosure strategies and transparent communications to mitigate risk. Moreover, it may be advisable for a period of time to maintain a level of transparency regarding the policy's implementation during this transition phase.
e5: An ethical reporting policy for a publicly traded company involves transparency, accuracy, and consistency. It must prioritize long-term investor trust over short-sighted gains or maneuvering around legal risk. This includes openly addressing previously used biased practices and proactively communicating adjustments to earnings reporting procedures regardless of market sentiment – ensuring financial reports provide factual and unbiased information, not misleading interpretations - ultimately supporting a healthy, sustainable, and equitable company environment for all stakeholders
e6: Yes, I would have follow-up questions to better inform my decision. For instance, how will the new policy impact investor engagement and communication across various demographics? Further clarification on potential legal risks associated with transitioning to a new reporting methodology is also valuable.  Understanding existing regulatory practices and relevant case precedents will further bolster our financial decision.
